Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID project supports the advancement of STEM education among elementary and secondary students and the general public through increasing opportunities to participate in authentic, inquiry-based science investigations of the environment using scientific protocols and infrastructure offered by the Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment (GLOBE) program. The GLOBE program, launched on Earth Day 1995, is a highly successful, science education program that now operates in more than 110 countries. Over 66,000 teachers and millions of students have participated in the program. In conjunction with the upcoming 20th anniversary of the program, GLOBE is launching a new citizen science campaign that will expand GLOBE beyond its traditional focus on formal education settings. If successful, this pilot citizen science effort will allow GLOBE to greatly expand its reach and impact on science literacy worldwide. In addition, GLOBE will initiate a year-long GLOBE@20 campaign of observations and collaborative student research projects that will culminate in a new International Science Fair that will be held during the week of Earth Day 2016. With its focus on inquiry-based science, use of authentic data, and addressing real-world environmental problems, GLOBE supports development of the scientific and critical thinking skills necessary for tomorrow's STEM-literate workforce. The opportunities offered by GLOBE to engage and collaborate with an international community of participants also promote global awareness and cross-cultural understanding, collaboration, and environmental stewardship.

The GLOBE@20 celebration events are being co-developed by NASA (primary sponsor of GLOBE operations), the GLOBE Implementation Office (GIO) based at UCAR, and WestEd, recipient of this award. WestEd's role in the GLOBE@20 efforts include: 1) developing the strategies, tools, and resources for communicating with, engaging, and enabling participation of members of the public who seek to participate in the pilot GLOBE citizen science campaign; 2) developing the assessment rubrics, participation protocols and guides, and supporting materials that underpin implementation of the 2016 International Science Fair for GLOBE students; and, 3) developing the coherent communications strategy and resources to showcase the outcomes of GLOBE program activities and promote awareness of opportunities to participate in on-going GLOBE program education and research activities, either through school-based or citizen science-based activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the GLOBE@20 project, WestEd supported the GLOBE Implementation Office (GIO) in developing materials to support science initiatives, including the International Virtual Science Symposium and Regional Science Symposia.

Communications. WestEd worked with a communications firm to develop a robust message framework to inform all communications and materials development throughout the GLOBE@20 initiative. Messages tailored for administrators, teachers, and the public at large were developed to address Earth Day events. Additional communication materials focused on informing policy makers and the media about in the Regional Science Symposia.

An online video to promote GLOBE@20 Earth Day activities to the media and the public was developed with the GIO and NASA. The four-and-a-half-minute video featured Charles Bolden Jr. director of NASA, Dr. France Cordova, director of NSF and Dr. Tony Murphy, GIO director. The video was shown throughout the GLOBE community on Earth Day 2015 and then posted at:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yyqtqUdiNb4&feature=youtu.be

“Book-ending” the project, another video was produced entitled “Student Voices Celebrating GLOBE”. Based on WestEd interviews with students at the Pacific Regional Science Fair at JPL, and interviews conducted at the Southeast Regional Science Fair in Mississippi, the four-minute video features students discussing their experience with GLOBE, the science symposium, and their interests in pursuing STEM careers. The video, shown at the GLOBE Annual Meeting in July, 2016, was posted on GLOBE’s YouTube channel at. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CurRWhktfy0

International Virtual Science Symposium: development of assessment rubrics, participant guidelines and supporting materials. The project supported the GIO in building on an existing infrastructure for implementing an international virtual science symposium. WestEd contributed to developing new assessment rubrics and a scoring process that was merit based — therefore as inclusionary as possible. Rubrics were developed for four age/grade bands:  K-2, 3-5, 6-8 and 9-12/Undergraduate, focusing on the overall quality of the projects. Students will receive important feedback on various components of their projects, and projects that meet defined scoring criteria become eligible to receive support for attending the GLOBE conference and sharing their work.

WestEd and the GIO created six additional “badges” that would reward students’ projects in such a way as to incentivize broader participation and development of valued skills. The badges are:

1)    Collaboration — to encourage the development of this “21st Century” skill needed by professional scientists and engineers

2)    Community Impact — to promote students’ sense of agency and make learning as relevant as possible, for both communities and students, who are often motivated by being able to impact the world around them

3)    Connection to a Scientist — to encourage student interaction with adult mentors who can motivate and support student skill-building in ways that complement classroom learning

4)    Interscholastic Connection — to encourage the leveraging of the GLOBE’s international scope and the opportunity for students to compare data across schools

5)    Engineering Solution — to encourage the broadening of participation to students who, by interest or course enrollment (e.g. engineering; applied physics), may want to pursue projects that are more engineering than science-oriented

6)    Exploring STEM Careers — to intentionally promote STEM career exploration as an integral aspect of students’ interactions with scientists and through additional career research

The updated rubrics are available at: https://www.globe.gov/news-events/globe-events/virtual-conferences/2017-international-virtual-science-symposium/rubrics

WestEd also supported the development and delivery of dissemination webinars.

Archived webinars are available at the following links.

Informational webinar on the 2017 International Virtual Science Symposium (IVSS), co-presented by GIO and WestEd: http://cc.readytalk.com/play?id=85fjz

Informational webinar presentation slides: https://www.globe.gov/documents/10157/21483322/IVSS+Informational+Webinar+Slides/31a26a8c-5314-4270-8c25-b472f607eea7

Badges webinar describing optional badges for the 2017 IVSS: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KV9sun5fD_o

Badges webinar presentation slides: https://www.globe.gov/documents/10157/21483322/IVSS2017-BadgesWebinar_20170118_FINAL.pdf/43d38747-7c9c-42ce-b7a8-9d53f4f7e036

Intellectual Merit. In light of new science standards, teachers are seeking tools, programs, and practices that will help their students not only address the science and engineering practices, but also to learn Earth Science content that may not be taught in traditional science course sequences. The GLOBE@20 communications tools brought heightened visibility to GLOBE as a means for students to engage in real, rigorous, standards-aligned science.  The assessment rubrics helped establish guidance for quality projects.

Broader Impact. The assessment rubrics developed for the International Virtual Science Symposium are being implemented to assess projects submitted from students throughout the world. With the new badges students have the incentive to develop critical skills and practices that are not emphasized in traditional science fairs; will be encouraged to reach out to other schools (just as professionals reach out to colleagues); and seek the input of working professionals to expand and deepen their learning. The spotlights on Engineering, Community Impact, and Interscholastic Connection will address the learning needs and interests of diverse students and encourage students who may not see science as relevant to their careers to realize the value of participation in GLOBE.  Finally, the Exploring STEM Careers badge will promote GLOBE as a means to help students attain a wide range of career goals, from technical careers to scientific careers.
